bibl.title: Memorandum from Philip Showalter Hench to The Surgeon General, U. S. Army, August 12, 1952

div1.p: Hench reports to Army Surgeon General [Armstrong] on the impending memorialization of Camp Lazear and the participation of the U.S. Army and State Department in the ceremony. Additional items covered include the tentative date for the dedication, the correct names of the volunteers, the name to be given the memorial, American representatives at the dedication, financial support of the current project, and future improvement of the project by American financial support.

div1.head: Memorandum from Philip Showalter Hench to The Surgeon General, U. S. Army, August 12, 1952
div1.opener:
Where is copy
Armstrongs letters to
Presno?
August 12, 1952
TO: The Surgeon General, United States Army FROM: Dr. Philip S. Hench
SUBJECT:

list.item:
(a) Impending Memorialization of the Historical Experimental Sani-
tary Station of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever Board, 1900 - 1901
(Walter Reed's “Camp Lazear”), in Quemados, Cuba, by the Cuban
Government, Department of Public Health and Sanitation, and

(b) Participation of the U. S. Army and State Department in the
Dedication Ceremony.

1. Memorializing the remains of “Camp Lazear” and of Walter Reed's
“Building No. 1.” After twelve years of prodding, the Cuban Government
(Doctor Andreu, the Minister of Health, assisted by Dr. Pedro Nogueira and
others) is about to memorialize the remains of Walter Reed's old experimental
station, Camp Lazear (at Quemados de Marianao, just outside Havana) and the
remains of the famous “Building No. 1.” Regarding the discovery of these
remains in 1940 by the writer and others, see enclosure 8. Regarding the
difficulties encountered by the writer and others in having this place pre-
served, see encl. 1a and 6. The “memorials” will consist of (a) the transforma-
tion of the remains of Camp Lazear into a small park; (b) the partial re-
pairing of the U.S. Army Yellow Fever Board's Building No. 1 (which however
will unfortunately still be left exposed to the elements); (c) the erection
of a decorative wall on which will appear medallions showing the profiles of
of Doctors Finlay, Delgado, Reed, Lazear, Carroll, Agramonte and General Wood;
(d) Bronze tablets identifying the spot and giving the names of certain
volunteers for the yellow fever experiments, i.e., certain American soldiers
(see enclosures 3-a, 3-b and 3-c).

2. Tentative date for the dedication. This is a little uncertain,
but the Cuban committee on arrangements hopes to dedicate the memorial at the
time of an international medical congress in Havana, either the Inter-American
Congress of Public Health, September 26 - October 1, or the International
Congress on Hygiene to be held late in September. I have received photographs
showing the progress of the project. Extensive grading has been done and it
may be that the dedication can be held as scheduled, but I personally wonder
whether they can complete the bronze tablets, wall, etc., in the next six or
seven weeks. However it is possible that the committee on arrangements may
decide to “dedicate” Camp Lazear at the time of the Congress even though the
permanent memorials are not ready.

3. The correct names of the volunteers to be memorialized on the
bronze tablets. For the committee in charge. Doctor Nogueira recently asked
me to give him the correct names of all of the volunteers. This was not easy
(see enclosure 5). It seemed desirable to obtain, if possible, the middle
names as well as the correct spelling of the names of the volunteers. I would
appreciate it greatly if the Surgeon General's Office would request the Ad-
jutant General's Department to send to me and/or to Doctor Nogueira* the
Dr. Nogueira's address: Dr. Pedro Nogueira, Marti 219. Marianao, Havana, Cuba
The Surgeon General
August 12, 1952
Page 2
middle names and correct spelling of the first and last names of the U. S.
Army personnel concerned, as listed annually in the Roll of Honor of the
Army Register, see enclosure 5, page 5. If this list could be made available
as soon as possible, it would be very helpful as they already are planning
the bronze tablets. If the Adjutant General does not have the full names,
I would appreciate it greatly if they would give me the addresses of the
surviving relatives, insofar as they have them, and I will at once get in
touch with them in order to obtain the desired information.

4. Name to be given the memorial. The small Cuban committee on
arrangements appears to be composed of three members, Dr. Jose Andreu,
Minister of Health, (chairman of the Committee), Dr. Pedro Nogueira (the
man who continues to “spark” the affair) and a third member who, I think,
may be the Mayor of Marianao. You are aware, I am sure, of the unfortunate
anti-Reed and anti-American attitude of Cuban medical and governmental
circles which has been held for 50 years, at least in certain circles.
Recently a small group of more tolerant, broad-minded and historically
accurate Cuban physicians have tried to change this attitude. Doctor
Nogueira is the current leader of this movement, as Dr. Domingo Ramos
(former Cuban Secretary of Defense) was the former leader of this movement.
I know that it is Doctor Nogueira's personal intention to have the names
“Camp Lazear” and “Building No. 1” (or “Caseta No. 1”) retained. But there
has been such a continuation or perpetuation of errors and nomenolature in
the Cuban newspapers the last three or four years as to make one suspect
that the Cuban press is in deliberate conspiracy to continue the anti-Reed,
pro-Finlay argument (see encl. 1b and 2). Thus the term “Parque Finlay” has
been used in lieu of “Camp Lazear,” and “Caseta de Finlay” in lieu of the
U.S. Army Yellow Fever Board's “Building No. 1.” Regarding Doctor Nogueira's
assurances that these errors will not be perpetuated and that the present
names will be applied to the memorial, see enclosure 7. I have asked two
or three Cubans, personal friends of mine who are unofficially interested
in the project, to keep me informed as to the attitude of the newspapers.
If it appears that the historical names of Camp Lazear and Building No. 1
are going to be changed despite Doctor Nogueira's efforts, it will be im-
portant, I think, to put upon those concerned discrete diplomatic pressure
at the proper time and place; perhaps the military attache of the American
Embassy in Havana could be informed confidentially about this matter and
could act for the moment as an unofficial observer. People in Havana who
would be very helpful if necessary, would be two American news correspondents
(one of them is the Havana correspondent of the New York Times), certain
friendly Cuban physicians and others whom I know.

item.p:
5. Participation of the U. S. Army, in particular the U. S.
Army Medical Corps, and the State Department in the dedication. It has
been the hopeful intention of those Cubans and the few Americans who have
been pushing this project that its dedication will introduce a new era of
good feeling among Cuban and American physicians in particular. As explained
in enclosure No. 1, (page 1), Camp Lazear can serve as a very useful rallying
point for this improved feeling, and as a site for a Cuban-American Memorial
The Surgeon General
August 12, 1952
Page 3
in honor of both Doctor Finlay and his associates and Major Reed and his
associates. I know it is the hope of many Cubans, as expressed by Doctor
Nogueira (enclosure 7) that the American Army and government will partici-
pate in the memorial.

In view of the long-standing and, at times acrimonious, feud,
the anti-Reed attitude in Cuba has not entirely died down. Although one
of the Cuban instigators of this feud died a few years ago, his place has
been taken by another very partisan Cuban, as is attested by recent news-
paper and magazine articles in my possession. Therefore, if the Cuban
Government and its Health Department do really intend now to memorialize
Camp Lazear and to perpetuate its proper historical names, they are making
a great concession and an outstanding contribution to Cuban-American
friendship, not only among medical circles but in lay circles. I can
testify personally that although there are innumerable memorials to Doctor
Finlay and even two or three rather minor memorials to Lazear, including a
bust of Lazear in Havana, the name of Major Walter Reed did not appear
anywhere until two or three years ago and this omission was deliberate.
However two or three years ago a painting was unveiled, which painting in-
cluded Doctor Finlay and the four members of the U. S. Army Yellow Fever
Commission.

6. American representatives at the dedication. When the Cuban
government invites the American government to send representatives of the
U. S. Army and/or State Department for the dedication, it is for others to
suggest who these delegates might be. Certainly it would be extremely
desirable to have one or more representatives from the Surgeon General's
Office, U. S. Army. Permit me to inquire as to whether Walter Reed's son,
Major General W. L. Reed, U. S. Army Retired (and his wife), General Albert
E. Truby, U. S. Army Medical Corps, Retired (and his wife) might be designated
in some way as representatives for the dedication? (This suggestion is
entirely my own but has the informal approval of Doctor Nogueira.) General
Truby was, for a while, commanding officer at the hospital at Camp Columbia
while Major Reed was doing his work there, and has written an authoritative
book on the conquest of yellow fever. I do not of course know by what means
Generals Reed and Truby might be made delegates or representatives, whether
they could be “reactivated” temporarily for this event if they are willing
to accept the assignment, or whether other American funds might be available
to them, assuming that the Cuban government might not have funds for this
purpose. Walter Reed's daughter, Mrs. Blossom Reed, should certainly be invited.

The son and daughter of Doctor Lazear*, the martyr of the Yellow
Fever Board, certainly deserve special consideration. They live in California.
Being civilians, they have no connection whatever with the State Department
or the U. S. Army. Whether or not the Cuban government would choose to do
more than to send them an official invitation (without travelling funds)
remains to be seen. The two living survivors of the U.S. Army Yellow Fever
Board's experiments are the former Army contract surgeon, Dr. Robert P.
Cooke, a retired physician of Lexington, Virginia, and the former Army
private, James L. Hanberry, of Orangeburg, South Carolina. Their presence
at the dedication would be most fitting.

*Mr. William Houston Lazear, P.O. Box 812, Santa Barbara, California
Mrs. W. D. Briggs. 106 The Uplands, Berkeley, California

list.item:
7. Financial Support of the Present Limited Memorial Project.
$25,000 was allotted by the Cuban government for the present project.
Therefore, aside from small sums of money which the writer has contributed
himself during the last twelve years for minor repairs to Building No. 1,
the money for the present project has been entirely given by the Cubans.

item.p:
8. Future Improvement of the Present Memorial Project: American
Financial Support. The permanent enclosure of Building No. 1 is a most
desirable objective and one which the present fund does not make possible.
But once the present limited project is concluded, it is the hope of certain
Cubans and Americans that money can be raised with which to enclose Building
No. 1 in a suitable “Cuban-American Memorial Building,” which building
however should be merely a sort of “museum room” connected with a more
functional type of memorial, possibly a small public health unit for the
Health Department of Quemados de Marianao. One of the drawbacks to the
establishment of this larger memorial has been the fact that the site of
Camp Lazear is, unfortunately, not in a very desirable location. It has
become surrounded by very modest homes of the working people. But to the
historically minded, this makes no difference because this is actually the
historic site and no other would be suitable.

I am making further direct inquiries of Doctor Nogueira regarding
the exact meaning of his comments on page 2 of enclosure 7, which comments
are numbered paragraph 6 (i.e., his remarks regarding those whom the Cuban
government might invite as guests). It is not clear to me whether or not
any traveling allowances might be made available by the Cuban government.
